bibl.author: The Walt Whitman Archive
bibl.title: Documents Related to the 1855 Leaves of Grass

body.head: Documents Related to the 1855 Leaves of Grass

div1.p: A number of peripheral documents are important to understanding the 1855 Leaves of Grass, from the copyright deposit page to the binders' receipts to a series of draft ads Whitman had printed. Here we provide images and a brief discussion of the context and significance of these documents. In the future, we hope to provide more extensive editorial treatment of these documents, including links to transcriptions.

div1.head: Production Documents
div1.p: A series of documents relate to the printing, binding, and deposit of the 1855 Leaves of Grass.
The binder's receipt shows the number of books bound in Binding A.
This draft copyright notice for the 1855 Leaves of Grass is written in another hand.

div1.head: Annotated Reviews
div1.p: Whitman annotated proofs and final versions of the reviews he had printed and bound into some copies of the 1855 Leaves of Grass.
These annotations on this final version of the insertion did not make it into the 1855 Leaves version. [Did they make it into any other version?]

div1.head: Autographed Frontispiece Prints
div1.p: A series of prints made of the frontispiece engraving are signed by Whitman in blue ink. Some of these are laid into copies of the 1855 Leaves of Grass.

div1.head: Early Draft Advertisements
div1.p: At some point Whitman had printed a series of what appear to be draft advertisements for the 1855 Leaves of Grass. He must have done this while he was still revising the poems, because one of them features draft lines from what would become the first poem in the volume, in later editions titled "Song of Myself." For more about Whitman's printed slips, see Michael Winship, "Walt Whitman," Bibliography of American Literature, Vol. 9 (New Haven: Yale University Press, 1991), 28-103; Jay Grossman, "Manuprint" (forthcoming in the Walt Whitman Quarterly Review), and Peter Stallybrass, "Manufacturing Manuscript: Walt Whitman's 'Slips'" (forthcoming in the Walt Whitman Quarterly Review).

div1.head: Whitman's Desk Copy
div1.p: The New York Public Library has Whitman's desk copy of the 1855 Leaves of Grass, into which he pasted manuscripts and other documents.
